title: How to Troubleshoot & Fix Flickering in Your TV

steps.title: Here are 5 of the most common causes of flickering in a TV.
steps.content: Here are 5 of the most common causes of flickering in a TV. Diagnose your issue at home by investigating these issues. Loose cable . Dust and debris build-up . Outdated firmware or software . Overheating . Incorrect refresh rate settings .

steps.title: Unplug it and plug it back in.
steps.content: Unplug it and plug it back in. The most frequently suggested tech solution is suggested for a reason. Disconnect the power cable from the TV or the wall and leave it unplugged for 20 seconds. Finally, plug the TV back into power and see if the screen still flickers. It might just be temporarily glitching and restarting the TV will help in this case.

steps.title: Check the connections.
steps.content: Check the connections. Whether you're using an HDMI cable or a USB plug-in, you want to make sure that anything connected to your TV is plugged in all the way and that no cords are damaged. Cables that aren't plugged in correctly or are damaged will lose data and your screen will flicker. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Clean your TV.
steps.content: Clean your TV. Use a lint-free cloth, like a microfiber rag, and wipe down your TV's screen and wires. If dust is clogging up ports, use compressed air to get rid of it. Dust can accumulate and cause electrical devices to malfunction, like causing your TV to flicker.

steps.title: Update your TV's firmware.
steps.content: Update your TV's firmware. Outdated firmware will get bugs, like causing your screen to flicker. How you update depends on the model and make of your TV, but you can generally find the Update option in Settings. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Let your TV cool down before using it again.
steps.content: Let your TV cool down before using it again. If you use your TV for extended periods of time, it can overheat. Touch your TV to see if it's too hot; it might be placed in a spot that's not good for ventilation (like inside a cabinet), or the internal fan stopped working. If the internal cooling fan doesn't work, you might have to take it to a professional to get it replaced, or this might be a sign to buy a new TV .

steps.title: Adjust the refresh rate.
steps.content: Adjust the refresh rate. If your TV's firmware is up-to-date, a too-high or too-low refresh rate can be the cause behind the flickering on your screen. Changing it depends on the make and model of your TV, but you will generally find the "Refresh Rate" options in Display Settings or Picture Options .
